questions.text: How many base pairs the human genome is made of?
questions.solution:
The human genome is the complete set of nucleic acid sequences for humans and is made up of 3.2 billion base pairs.

It is encoded as DNA within the 23 chromosomes (haploid).

In 2007, a multinational project called Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) concluded that about 80% of the human genome does not code for the proteins. However, they allow for the binding of proteins or are involved in the regulation of gene expression, in a cell type-specific fashion. They are known as functional non-protein-coding genes.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the non-coding regulatory RNAs?

choices.text: Transcribed from protein-coding regions of DNA and translated to regulatory proteins
Transcribed from protein-coding regions of DNA but never translated
Transcribed from non-protein-coding regions of DNA and translated to regulatory proteins
Transcribed from non-protein-coding regions of DNA but never translated

questions.solution:
The non-coding regulatory RNAs are the functional non-protein-coding regions of the DNA, which are transcribed to RNA but are never translated into proteins.

The two important types of non-coding regulatory RNAs are the micro RNA (miRNA) and the long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs). These RNAs play an important role in the regulation of gene expression.

questions.text: What is the study of heritable changes in gene expression that are not caused by alterations in DNA sequence?
questions.solution:
Epigenetics is the branch of molecular biology that deals with the study of heritable changes in gene function not involving changes in the DNA sequence.

These heritable changes involve factors that mediate processes such as:

  • Histone organization 
  • DNA methylation 
  • Chromatin organization

These in turn regulate the genomic organization and gene expression in a cell-type-specific fashion. The dysregulation of these epigenomic factors plays a major role in the development of malignancy.

Green tea catechins have been reported to modulate epigenetic processes. They can reverse DNA methylation of tumor suppressor genes and increase the transcription of these genes.

questions.text: Micro-RNA are involved during which of the following stages?
questions.solution:
Micro-RNAs (miRNA) act during the post-transcriptional stage.

It is a type of non-coding RNA. The primary function of miRNA is to modulate the translation of target mRNAs into their corresponding proteins. After the target RNA is transcribed from its gene (post-transcriptional), the miRNA may either induce mRNA cleavage or repress its translation. This is referred to as gene silencing.

Small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) are short RNA sequences that can be introduced experimentally into cells. They have functions similar to endogenous miRNA (serve as substrates for the Dicer enzyme and interact with the RNA-induced silencing complex). They may have a therapeutic role in silencing certain oncogenes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about microRNAs?

choices.text: They are involved in cell differentiation and carcinogenesis
Mature forms of microRNAs are single stranded
They can suppress tumor suppressor genes

questions.solution:
MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small noncoding, single-stranded RNAs. They are approximately 22 nucleotides in length.

MicroRNAs mediate inhibition of messenger RNA (mRNA) translation through the action of the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC). They control normal cell growth, differentiation, and cell survival. miRNA can be of 2 types:

  • Tumour-suppressive miRNAs - decrease the translation of oncogenic mRNAs 
  • Onco-miRNAs - suppress tumor-suppressor genes

Other noncoding RNAs include:

  • piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) - involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing
  • snoRNAs - involved in maturation of rRNA, assembly of ribosomes and noncoding RNAs
  • lncRNAs - regulate the activity of chromatin 'writers', which modify histones and control gene expression

questions.text: What is the most common cause of cell injury?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia is the most common cause of cell injury.

Causes of cell injury include:

  • Hypoxia
  • Physical agents
  • Chemical agents and drugs
  • Infectious agents
  • Immunologic reactions
  • Genetic abnormalities
  • Nutritional imbalances

The mechanism of hypoxic cell injury is reduced oxidative respiration. The most common cause of hypoxia is ischemia.

Hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) is a transcription factor with protective effects against hypoxic injury such as:

  • Promotion of blood vessel formation
  • Stimulation of cell-survival pathways
  • Enhancement of anaerobic glycolysis

The cells most sensitive to hypoxia are neurons. The most sensitive neurons include:

  • Pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus (especially, area CA1, also known as Sommer’s sector)
  • Cerebellar Purkinje cells
  • Pyramidal neurons in the cerebral cortex

The cells most resistant to hypoxia are fibroblasts.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Atrophy is a type of reversible cell injury
Plasma membrane blebbing occurs in reversible cell injury
On removal of stimulus, necrosis can be reversed
Chronic sublethal stimulus can cause cellular aging

questions.solution:
On removal of stimulus, necrosis cannot be reversed. It is an irreversible cell injury.

Cellular adaptations are the reversible responses where the cells achieve an altered steady state in response to physiologic or some pathologic stimuli. They can be reversed if the stimulus causing stress or injury is removed. These cellular adaptations include:

  • Hypertrophy
  • Hyperplasia
  • Atrophy
  • Metaplasia

Chronic sublethal stimuli are unable to cause cell death but may lead to certain changes in cells, such as:

  • Intracellular accumulations
  • Pathological calcifications
  • Cellular aging

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of reversible cell injury?

choices.text: Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria
Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER

questions.solution:
Small amorphous densities are seen in the mitochondria in reversible cell injury.

The following changes occur in reversible cell injury:

  • Cellular swelling - earliest change
    • ATP depletion leads to sodium-potassium pump failure
    • Na and water accumulate within the cell causing cellular swelling
  • Fatty change -
    • Seen in cells involved in or dependent on fat metabolism (liver hepatocytes and myocardial cells)
  • Light microscopy - no noticeable changes
  • Ultrastructural findings -
    • Mitochondrial swelling and small amorphous densities
    • Plasma membrane blebs
    • Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
    • Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER
    • Nuclear changes like disaggregation of granular and fibrillar filaments

Note: The formation of large amorphous densities in the mitochondria is a feature of irreversible injury.

questions.text: Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell injury?

choices.text: Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

questions.solution:
Nuclear changes like pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis are features of irreversible cell injury visible on light microscopy.

The ultrastructural findings visible on electron microscopy include: 

  • Large amorphous floccular densities in mitochondria
  • Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
  • Ribosomal detachment from endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by:
questions.solution:
Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

Thrombosis is is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system. 

Three primary abnormalities, often referred to as Virchow triad, are known to induce thrombosis. They include:

  • Endothelial injury - most important factor
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cellular adaptations is correct?

choices.text: Hyperplasia involves synthesis of intracellular components
Atrophy is defined as decrease in cell size
Atrophy is the decrease in number and size of cells
Metaplasia is an irreversible replacement of a cell by another cell type

questions.solution:
Atrophy is a reduction in the size of an organ or tissue due to a decrease in cell size and number.

Cellular adaptations are reversible changes in the size, number, phenotype, metabolic activity, or functions of cells in response to changes in their environment. There are 4 types:

  • Hypertrophy -
    • Increase in organ size due to an increase in the size of cells
    • Involves synthesis and assembly of intracellular structural components
  • Hyperplasia - 
    • Increase in organ size due to an increase in the number of cells
    • It is due to division and proliferation of stem cells
  • Atrophy - reduction in organ size due to a decrease in cell size and number.
  • Metaplasia - one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type

questions.text: A patient with long-standing hypertension develops left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following transcription factors do not play a role in this?
questions.solution:
HNF is a transcription factor involved in the development of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), not the development of cardiac hypertrophy.

The transcription factors involved in cardiac muscle hypertrophy are:

  • GATA4 – hypertrophic stimuli result in enhanced DNA-binding activity of GATA-4
  • MEF2- increases due to pressure and volume overload
  • NFAT (Nuclear Factor for Activated T-cells)

questions.text: How does myosin change during muscle hypertrophy?

choices.text: From α-heavy chain to β-heavy chain
From β-heavy chain to α-heavy chain
From β-light chain to α-light chain
From α-light chain to β-light chain

questions.solution:
During muscle hypertrophy, the α-isoform of the myosin heavy chain is replaced by the β-isoform. It produces slower and more energetically economic contraction.

During hypertrophy, there may occur a switch of contractile proteins from the adult isoforms to the fetal or infantile isoforms.

questions.text: Both physiological hyperplasia and hypertrophy are simultaneously seen in which of the following individuals?

choices.text: A 24-year-old man vigorously training for an athletic race
A 35-year-old woman regularly taking combined oral contraceptive pills
A 50-year-old man with proliferation of liver cells following transplantation
A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 22 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Physiological hypertrophy and hyperplasia can be simultaneously seen in the uterus during pregnancy.

In early pregnancy, uterine growth is due to hyperplasia of uterine smooth muscle cells; however, the predominant growth of the uterus during pregnancy occurs after mid-gestation, by way of stretch‐induced myometrial hypertrophy.

Simultaneous physiological hypertrophy and hyperplasia also occur in the female breast during puberty and pregnancy.

Option A: Enlargement of skeletal muscles in athletes is an example of physiological hypertrophy.

Option B: Combined oral contraceptive pills causing endometrial hyperplasia is an example of pathological hyperplasia.

Option C: Following transplantation of a liver lobe, the remaining liver cells proliferate so that the organ grows back to its original size (compensatory hyperplasia).

questions.text: Which among the following do not usually undergo hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Skeletal muscle and heart muscle usually undergo hypertrophy, not hyperplasia.

Examples of physiologic hyperplasia:

  • Female breast during puberty and pregnancy (hormonal hyperplasia)
  • Uterine smooth muscle during early pregnancy
  • Compensatory hyperplasia of liver cells after partial resection

Examples of pathologic hyperplasia:

  • Endometrial hyperplasia
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of physiological atrophy?

choices.text: Atrophy of the legs of a bedridden patient
Atrophy of the arm muscles following a nerve injury
Muscle wasting in a child suffering from marasmus
Uterine atrophy after delivery by Cesarean-section

questions.solution:
Uterine atrophy following delivery is an example of physiological atrophy.

Atrophy is defined as a reduction in the size of an organ or tissue due to a decrease in cell size and number.

The following mechanisms are involved in atrophy:

  • Decreased protein synthesis due to decreased metabolic activity
  • Increased destruction of proteins by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway

The various types of atrophy are:

Stimulus/type of atrophy Example
Physiologic atrophy
Loss of hormonal stimulation

Atrophy of the uterus after parturition

Atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast after menopause
During embryonic development Certain structures, like notochord and thyroglossal duct
Pathologic atrophy
Disuse atrophy (decreased workload) Atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply) Skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
Ischemic atrophy Senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
Inadequate nutrition Severe muscle wasting in marasmus
Pressure atrophy Atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: The cross-section of the brain of an 84-year-old man with dyslipidemia is given below, in comparison with a normal brain. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change?
questions.solution:
The given image shows narrowing of gyri and widening of sulci in a senile brain, which is suggestive of senile atrophy. It is due to a gradual decrease in blood supply as a result of atherosclerosis, known as ischemic atrophy.

The various types of pathological atrophy are:

Pathologic atrophy 
Disuse atrophy (decreased workload) Atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply) Skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
Ischemic atrophy Senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
Inadequate nutrition Severe muscle wasting in marasmus
Pressure atrophy Atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is  the most common type of metaplasia?
questions.solution:
The most common type of metaplasia is squamous metaplasia, in which the normal columnar cells are replaced by squamous epithelial cells.

 The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia Cause
Airways Squamous metaplasia: Normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. 

Chronic smoking,

Deficiency of retinoic acid
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: Normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. Bladder stones 
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: Normal squamous epithelium is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barrett's esophagus) Chronic GERD
Cervix Squamous metaplasia: Normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium Low pH of the cervix
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: Formation of bone in the muscle tissue; (myositis ossificans) Following intramuscular hemorrhage

GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called:
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia Cause
Airways Squamous metaplasia: Normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. 

Chronic smoking,

Deficiency of retinoic acid
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: Normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. Bladder stones 
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: Normal squamous epithelium is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus) Chronic GERD 
Cervix Squamous metaplasia: Normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium. Low pH of the cervix
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: Formation of bone in the muscle tissue; (myositis ossificans). After intramuscular hemorrhage

GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is an example of connective tissue metaplasia?
questions.solution:
Myositis ossificans is an example of connective tissue metaplasia.

It refers to the formation of cartilage, bone, or adipose tissue (mesenchymal tissues) in tissues that normally do not contain these elements.

Myositis ossificans is characterised by bone formation within muscle tissue following traumatic injury to the area. However, this type of metaplasia is less clearly seen as an adaptive response.

questions.text: Deficiency in which of the following vitamins can lead to metaplastic transformation in the lung?
questions.solution: The deficiency of vitamin A (retinoic acid) induces squamous metaplasia in the respiratory epithelium.

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to:

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.solution:
Anaplasia refers to a lack of differentiation.

The term anaplasia means to form backward implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level. The extent to which neoplastic cells resemble normal cells, both morphologically and functionally, is called differentiation.

Anaplasia is an important morphological feature of malignant transformation.

The morphological features of malignancy include:

  • Anaplasia
  • Pleomorphism - variation in the size and shape of cells
  • Increased N: C ratio (nucleus: cytoplasmic ratio) - around 1:4 in normal cells, increases to 1:1 in malignant cells
  • Hyperchromasia - coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei
  • Increased mitosis - atypical, bizarre mitotic figures
  • Loss of polarity - sheets or large masses of tumor cells grow in an anarchic, disorganized fashion
